description: Learned borrowing from New Latin derma, from Ancient Greek δέρμα (dérma, “skin, hide”). Doublet of derm.

entries.meaning: The inner layer of the skin.

description: Borrowed from Yiddish דערמע‎ (derme), plural of דאַרם‎ (darm, “intestine”), from Middle High German [Term?], from Old High German darm, from Proto-West Germanic *þarm, from Proto-Germanic *þarmaz, from Proto-Indo-European *terh₁- (“to bore”).

entries.meaning: A Jewish dish of roast or boiled seasoned meat and flour etc. in a casing, especially kishke.
